Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC Forward Funding Year 1-4: Collaborative Research: Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
I/UCRC for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications

1034729 Ohio State University; Sudarsanam Babu
1034695 University of Wisconsin-Madison; Sindo Kou
1034703 Lehigh University; John DuPont
1034628 Colorado School of Mines; Stephen Liu

The Center for Integrative Materials Joining Science for Energy Applications will focus on the diverse need for materials in energy industries, and on developing scientific methodologies to join these materials and predict their lifetime. Ohio State University (OSU), University of Wisconsin-Madison (UW), Lehigh University (LU) and Colorado School of Mines (CSM) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with Ohio State University as the lead institution.

The intellectual merit of the proposed center is to "close the gap" between material development and weldability for materials used in the energy industry. The new knowledge generated will be used to (a) extend the life of material joints within the aging energy infrastructure and (b) increasing efficiency in deploying advanced materials for new energy infrastructure. The focus of the proposed center is to also address the critical need for engineering graduates trained in interdisciplinary methodologies to address materials joining for wide range of energy applications. The PIs are proposing the following research areas: joining of existing materials; joining of new advanced materials; joining of dissimilar materials; additive manufacturing for hybrid materials; and life extension of existing joints. The PIs are well-qualified and have adequate resources to conduct the proposed research.

The proposed center will focus on developing joining methodologies that will eventually become core components of the curriculum within welding and joining engineering programs. The proposed Center will also offer mentoring programs for students from different ethnic backgrounds and underrepresented groups. If successful, the scientific methodologies will be used to develop state-of-the-art simulation tools that could benefit several industries.

The defined concept for the center should provide an increase in the opportunity for different industries to participate in fundamental research. The center should provide an organized structure for drawing interest and projects from industry. In addition, the center should improve the potential for better understanding of advanced joining metallurgy.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has two significant outcomes. First, the tendency for cracking along the weld edge of magnesium (Mg) alloys can now be predicted. During welding, the material in the weld melts completely, while the material in the workpiece next to the weld melts partially. If the weld solidifies earlier than the workpiece next to it, that is, if the weld has a higher fraction solid fS than the workpiece at a given temperature T near the end of solidification. The solidifying and hence contracting weld can tear the solidifying workpiece (weaker due to its lower fS) to cause it to crack along the weld edge. Based on the compositions of the weld and the workpiece, commercially software can be used to plot their curves of T vs. fS. The susceptibility to weld edge cracking exists if (weld fS) > (workpiece fS) during solidification. This simple criterion can be a useful guide to selection of existing filler metals or search for new ones to suppress weld edge cracking.

The second outcome is the advancement of the science and technology of Mg welding. Gas-metal arc (also called MIG) welding, a versatile welding process widely used for aluminum alloys and steels, has not been used much for Mg alloys because of severe spatter. This project demonstrated successful welding of Mg alloys by an advanced MIG welding process called CSC-MIG, which used controlled short circuiting (CSC) to eliminate spatter. Furthermore, it was found that four other defects can easily occur in MIG welding of Mg alloys, including gas porosity and oxide films inside the weld, high crowns at the top of butt welds, and “fingers” sticking out from the side of lap welds. The mechanisms of formation of the five defects were established and effective methods to eliminate them were demonstrated. High quality welds with 98% of the workpiece strength were made. The findings in this project can be expected to help accelerate the use of Mg alloys in vehicle weight reduction to reduce fuel consumption and air pollution. 

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2015
Modified by: Sindo Kou

    Weld Edge Cracking
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has two significant outcomes. First, the tendency for cracking along the weld edge of magnesium (Mg) alloys can now be predicted. During welding, the material in the weld melts completely, while the material in the workpiece next to the weld melts partially. If the weld solidifies earlier than the workpiece next to it, that is, if the weld has a higher fraction solid fS than the workpiece at a given temperature T near the end of solidification. The solidifying and hence contracting weld can tear the solidifying workpiece (weaker due to its lower fS) to cause it to crack along the weld edge. Based on the compositions of the weld and the workpiece, commercially software can be used to plot their curves of T vs. fS. The susceptibility to weld edge cracking exists if (weld fS) > (workpiece fS) during solidification. This simple criterion can be a useful guide to selection of existing filler metals or search for new ones to suppress weld edge cracking. The second outcome is the advancement of the science and technology of Mg welding. Gas-metal arc (also called MIG) welding, a versatile welding process widely used for aluminum alloys and steels, has not been used much for Mg alloys because of severe spatter. This project demonstrated successful welding of Mg alloys by an advanced MIG welding process called CSC-MIG, which used controlled short circuiting (CSC) to eliminate spatter. Furthermore, it was found that four other defects can easily occur in MIG welding of Mg alloys, including gas porosity and oxide films inside the weld, high crowns at the top of butt welds, and "fingers" sticking out from the side of lap welds. The mechanisms of formation of the five defects were established and effective methods to eliminate them were demonstrated. High quality welds with 98% of the workpiece strength were made. The findings in this project can be expected to help accelerate the use of Mg alloys in vehicle weight reduction to reduce fuel consumption and air pollution.
